Argons are not exactly living and not exactly machines. Near as I can tell, they're created by other argons, but that still leaves a lot of questions unanswered. Why do some of them look like other forms of life? What's the point of that?

And what do they run on? I've never seen one eat anything.Next page.Close the book.

One day, we saw an immense, dark bird gliding over the valley. It started dropping something—eggs, maybe?

The "eggs" contained some kind of proto-argons that joined together in different combinations. Argons that self-assemble. Troubling.

We've run out of food, and the argons have poisoned everything here, so we can't forage.Previous page.Next page.Close the book.

Sashike died today. I don't quite know how to write this, or even if I can, but I'll try.

The argons separated us—a tactical move we weren't ready for. They took her down quickly, and then swarmed over her body like giant insects.

I killed as many as I could. They didn't seem to notice. Finally they pulled apart, each with a piece of her, and ran away, leaving me behind.Previous page.Next page.Close the book.

Today I caught a glimpse of the argons' queen. They call her Shandra Manaya.

That's right—they speak. Or the smart ones do. Calling it speech isn't quite right, though. To my ears, it's eerie clicking mixed with words.

Did Shandra Manaya create the argons? If so, she must be a goddess. What chance do we have against an immortal argon?Previous page.Next page.Close the book.

I saw them digging up something huge near a circular building. They took it toward the north side, but I'm too weak to follow.

The queen is north of here, somewhere. Probably close—too close.

Tell Hekasha what happened. Don't let them take me.Previous page.Close the book.
